TopicTitle: The latest thing happening in space, as told by the Kerbal Daily Globe (page 23)

Articles.Content:
The following account, while it takes its inspiration from real events, may or may not have been compiled by a wet-behind-the-ears Kerbal Daily Globe correspondent sent to KSC to cover "all that space stuff", and therefore may represent an entirely uninformed perspective upon what happened.

KERBAL SPACE CENTER ASTRONAUT COMPLEX. YEAR 1, DAY 5

Dok-dok...dok-dok...dok-dok..."OW!" "Sorry!"...dok-dok. "Soo.... what's the mission for today, Gene? We... OW.... finally going to start picking up some satellite contracts? Or are we... OW... trying for a docking? I think I've got the hang of this rendezvous thing now -OW-," queried Jeb, trying to referee a Ping-Ponk game between Bill and Bob. Neither opponent was terribly good at the game, so most of the shots ended up hitting Jeb instead of the table.

"Nope. We've decided to send you to the Mun."

"The Mun? For Kol's sake, I've only done one flyby! And that was on a dare!" cried Jeb.

"Well, regardless, we've got you penciled in for tomorrow. Today is all mission prep."

"Alright, as long as you've got a design that can get me there and back. I don't want to have to wait for a rescue mission."

"Would we be talking if we didn't?"

"True."

KSC LAUNCHPAD. YEAR 1, DAY 6.

Bill's voice came in over the comms, which everybody, myself included, were listening in on thanks to a couple of very loud ham radio enthusiasts. Personally, I wanted to hear the news, or maybe that techno station from Kurich. But it wasn't as if I had a choice in the matter. "Alright, Jeb, if you do everything right, she'll have a bit of fuel left in the tank for you to do some biome-hopping. Just sit back, relax, and don't touch anything. The autopilot will handle everything... fantastic invention."

"How much transit time are we talking about here?"

"Not very much, really. Eet is only three days total there and back. Seence we do not have ze proper technology yit to do long-term research on ze Mun, ju weel speend at most five hours on ze surface of ze Mun."

"What?"

"COUGH kaff. Apologies, it is my throat again. As I was saying, ze trip is only three days there and back again. You'll spend roughly five hours on ze surface of the Mun, and ze rest of the trip in transit. I would advise you to bring a book."

"Bit late for that, Wernher, seeing as we're at T minus twenty minutes..."

"Zen why dit ju ask now? Vhy did you nut ask fifteen hours earlier, vehn ve vehre strapping ju in? Das..." von Kermann's comms channel suddenly cut out. "Sorry about that, Jebediah. Count von Kermann hit the brew a bit hard last night..." supplied Bob.

"Eh, heck, whatever. As long as the rocket's fine, I'm fine. Let's get it over with and launch this thing." sighed Jeb.

"Jeb, it's still T minus nineteen minutes."

"Why not launch now? It's all fueled and everything..."

"Intercept windows or... something. Look, I'm sure Gene had a very good reason for timing the launch like this."

"Where's Gene, then. I want to talk to Gene."

"Wait, I thought you knew where Gene was."

"What-"

19 MINUTES LATER.

"-and that's why you should never date a woman who claims to play the sousaphone. Anyways, folks, thanks for coming to the first Mun launch in history and HOLY KRAKEN IT'S ON FIRE EVERYBODY RUN FOR YOUR LIVES WHY WAS I NOT TOLD ABOUT THIS!"

The announcer had no idea what he was talking about. Everything went perfectly. Six LVT-30s fired in unison all the way up until they ran themselves out of fuel. Then BANG, something blew up. Then two Mk. 55s fired. Then they stopped. Then they fired again. Then they stopped. Then there was another bang. Then a single Mk. 55 fired. Then it stopped.

"Ach, Krakenspew. He had to use a bit of the lander stage to circularize." complained Wernher.

Apparently something went mildly wrong, but since a certain Gene Kermann was not available for color commentary, nobody knew. All they saw was rockets going on and off and exploding and on and off and exploding and on and off.

Then some time went by.

SOME TIME LATER

The Mk. 55 fired again. This kept on for a tick.

A TICK LATER

The Mk. 55 stopped firing. The signal on the little TV switched to a Kongressional budget hearing. Everybody, myself included, got up and left the stands. On the way out, I saw the ham radio enthusiasts slow-roasting their hams. Must be an expensive hobby.

Does our intrepid reporter get fired from his job for idiocy? Does the KSC find Gene? Does von Kermann finally sober up long enough to design some Skippers? Find out next time on...

On...

Harvin. Dude. Your line.

Harvin?

Harvin!

Ah, krap.
